answers.answer: Dear Binky:Sorry that your having paraesthesias.  I am not sure what to tell you as you did not explain how the diagnosis was made.  A slightly pinched nerve in the neck can mean alot of things.  Is the cervical cord compromised by a disc herniation, is there some slight foramen narrowing?  What did the EMG show?  What was your B12 level? Do you have a compounding illness such as diabetes?  Do you drink alcohol heavily?  Do you have lupus?  etc.  I would suggest that you sit down with your physician and discuss your worries and what the possible etiology of your cervical problem might be.  Then I would take every effort in trying to correct the problem.Sincerely,CCF Neuro MD
Until the Neurologist responds, you can find good info @ the following Web site:http://www.lenfunk.btinternet.co.uk/Orthspinecdisc.htm

Hi Binky,I'm sorry to hear you are having such difficulties with obtaining a correct diagnosis.  I truly understand how you feel.I am a 42 yo female, and, I, personally am dealing with a C3-4 pinched nerve due to degenerative disk disease.  For the past year I have been being diagnosed as having a "shoulder impingement syndrome and/or a rotator cuff syndrome.  The and/or is dependent upon which physician I see.  As of the week of 7/18, I was diagnosed with a completely different medical problem of which has been causing the extreme shoulder pain.  Please talk with your physician about your concerned issues as this is extremely important, not only for treatment and healing purposes, but for your mental status as well.  My physician wants to treat me with a "epidural steroid injection", of which after reading information online, I have determined it to be of great "high risk" for further damage in the future depending on the steroids they choose to use.  It's very depressing to wonder if I will be, like you, on pain killers for the rest of my life.  Good luck, and one more thing, get more than one opinion.  I have learned that a physicians' opinions are quite different and varied.  Also, you might check out this website: www.spineuniverse.com, as it may be able to provide you with some detailed information regarding your questions.Take care,Geckowon

question: I have been diagnosed with having cervical myelopathy.  In doing research I find that the classical symptoms are not the ones I have.  I have numbness in my toes and also tingling as though they were asleep. I have a burning sensation in my legs up to the knees.  My doctor has given my no medication and just checks every 6 months my relexes and strenght.  I am alot of discomfort and wonder if I should seek another opinion on these.  I am very discouraged.  I have had these symptoms for over a year.   Have had MRI on entire back and all it shows is a slight pinching of the nerve in my neck.  Any answer you can give me will be a help.
title: cervical myelopathy
